This is a list of [countries](/wiki/Countries "Countries") by [system of
government](/wiki/System_of_government "System of government"). There is also
a [political mapping](/wiki/Map "Map") of the world that shows what form of
government each country has, as well as a brief description of what each form
of government entails. The list is colour-coded according to the type of
government, for example: blue represents a republic with an executive head of
state, and red is a constitutional monarchy with a ceremonial head of state.
The colour-coding also appears on the following map, representing the same
government categories. The legend of what the different colours represent is
found just below the map.

###
Legend[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Legend")]

  * Presidential [republics](/wiki/Republic "Republic") with a full [presidential system](/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system")

  * Presidential republics with a [semi-presidential system](/wiki/Semi-presidential_system "Semi-presidential system")

  * [Parliamentary republics](/wiki/Parliamentary_republic "Parliamentary republic") with an [executive presidency](/wiki/President#Parliamentary_systems "President") [dependent on the legislature](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system")

  * [Parliamentary republics](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") with a ceremonial/non-executive president, where a separate head of government leads the executive

  * [Constitutional monarchy](/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy "Constitutional monarchy") with a ceremonial monarch, where a separate head of government leads the executive

  * [Constitutional monarchy](/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy "Constitutional monarchy") which have with a separate head of government, but where royalty still hold significant executive and/or legislative power

  * [Absolute monarchy](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy")

  * Countries where the dominant role of [political party](/wiki/One-party_state "One-party state") is codified in the constitution

  * Countries in which constitutional provisions for government have been suspended (e.g. [military dictatorship](/wiki/Military_dictatorship "Military dictatorship"))

  * Countries which do not fit any of the above systems (e.g. transitional government or unclear political situations)

  * No government

Note: this chart represent _[de jure](/wiki/De_jure "De jure")_ systems of
government, not the _[de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")_ degree of
democracy. Several states constitutionally republics, broadly appear as
authoritarian states.

## Systems of
governance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Systems of governance")]

_Italics_ indicate states with limited recognition.

### Presidential/Separated
republics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Presidential/Separated republics")]

These are systems in which a [president](/wiki/President "President") is the
active head of the [executive branch](/wiki/Executive_branch "Executive
branch") of government and is elected and remains in office independently of
the [legislature](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature"). The following list
includes democratic and non-democratic states:

#### Full presidential
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Full presidential systems")]

In full [presidential systems](/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential
system"), the president is both head of state and head of government. There is
generally no prime minister, although if one exists, in most cases, he or she
serves purely at the discretion of the president (with the exceptions being
Belarus and Kazakhstan, where the prime minister is effectively the head of
government).[1][2]

#### Semi-presidential
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Semi-presidential systems")]

In [semi-presidential systems](/wiki/Semi-presidential_system "Semi-
presidential system"), there is always both a president and a prime minister.
In such systems, the president has genuine executive authority, unlike in a
parliamentary republic, but the role of a head of government may be exercised
by the [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_minister "Prime minister").

### Parliamentary
republics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Parliamentary republics")]

A [parliamentary republic](/wiki/Parliamentary_republic "Parliamentary
republic") is a system in which a [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_minister "Prime
minister") is the active head of the [executive branch](/wiki/Executive_branch
"Executive branch") of government and also leader of the
[legislature](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature"). The president's degree of
executive power may range from being reasonably significant to little (e.g.
India), to only having certain limited reserve powers (e.g. Ireland) or none
at all. Where the president holds little executive power, his or her function
is primarily that of a symbolic [figurehead](/wiki/Figurehead "Figurehead").

#### Mixed republican
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Mixed republican systems")]

A combined head of state and government is elected by the legislature, however
they are not subject to parliamentary confidence during their term (although
their cabinet may be); the exceptions are [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa
"South Africa"), where the president may be forced to resign by the
Parliament's will,[6] and [Kiribati](/wiki/Kiribati "Kiribati"), where the
president is popularly elected and a successful parliamentary motion of no
confidence automatically triggers a new presidential election.

### Directorial
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Directorial systems")]

In the [directorial system](/wiki/Directorial_system "Directorial system") a
council jointly exercises both state functions and governmental powers (the
council is the collective head of state and government). The council is
elected by the parliament, but it is not subject to [political
confidence](/wiki/Confidence_\(political_science\) "Confidence \(political
science\)") during its term which has a fixed duration.

### Constitutional
monarchies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Constitutional monarchies")]

These are systems in which the [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of
state") is a [constitutional monarch](/wiki/Constitutional_monarch
"Constitutional monarch"); the existence of their office and their ability to
exercise their authority is established and restrained or held back by
constitutional law.

#### Constitutional monarchies with ceremonial
monarchs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Constitutional monarchies with ceremonial monarchs")]

Systems in which a [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_minister "Prime minister") is
the active head of the [executive branch](/wiki/Executive_branch "Executive
branch") of government. In some cases the prime minister is also leader of the
[legislature](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature"), in other cases the executive
branch is clearly separated from legislature although the entire cabinet or
individual ministers must step down in the case of a [vote of no
confidence](/wiki/Vote_of_no_confidence "Vote of no
confidence").[12][13][_[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") –
[discuss](/wiki/Talk:List_of_countries_by_system_of_government#Constitutional_monarchy
"Talk:List of countries by system of government")_] The [head of
state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state") is a [constitutional
monarch](/wiki/Constitutional_monarch "Constitutional monarch") who normally
only exercises his or her powers with the consent of the government, the
people or their representatives.

### One-party
states[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: One-party states")]

States in which political power is _by law_ concentrated within [one political
party](/wiki/One-party_state "One-party state") whose operations are largely
fused with the government hierarchy (as opposed to states where the law
establishes a [multi-party system](/wiki/Multi-party_system "Multi-party
system") but [this fusion is not achieved anyway through electoral fraud or
simple inertia](/wiki/Dominant-party_system "Dominant-party system")).
However, some do have elected governments.

###
Federal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Federal")]

Main article: [Federal state](/wiki/Federal_state "Federal state")

## European
Union[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_system_of_government&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: European Union")]

Main article: [List of European Union member states by political
system](/wiki/List_of_European_Union_member_states_by_political_system "List
of European Union member states by political system")

The exact political character of the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union
"European Union") is debated, some arguing that it is _[sui
generis](/wiki/Sui_generis "Sui generis")_ (unique), but others arguing that
it has features of a [federation](/wiki/Federation "Federation") or a
[confederation](/wiki/Confederation "Confederation"). It has elements of
[intergovernmentalism](/wiki/Intergovernmentalism "Intergovernmentalism"),
with the [European Council](/wiki/European_Council "European Council") acting
as its collective "president", and also elements of
[supranationalism](/wiki/Supranationalism "Supranationalism"), with the
[European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") acting
as its executive and bureaucracy.[21] But it is not easily placed in any of
the above categories.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Arter's own conclusions are only slightly more nuanced: "The adoption of a new constitution on 1 March 2000 meant that Finland was no longer a case of semi-presidential government other than in the minimalist sense of a situation where a popularly elected fixed-term president exists alongside a prime minister and cabinet who are responsible to parliament (Elgie 2004: 317)". According to the Finnish Constitution, the President has no possibility to rule the government without the ministerial approval, and substantially has not the power to disband the parliament under its own desire. Finland is actually represented by its Prime Minister, and not by its President, in the Council of the Heads of State and Government of the European Union. The 2012 constitutional amendments reduced the powers of the President even further.

She is titled separately in each country (e.g. [Queen of Australia](/wiki/Queen_of_Australia "Queen of Australia")), and notionally appoints a [Governor-General](/wiki/Governor-General "Governor-General") to each country other than the United Kingdom to act as her representative. The [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_minister "Prime minister") is the active head of the executive branch of government and also leader of the legislature. New Zealand and its associated states, along with [Tokelau](/wiki/Tokelau "Tokelau") and the [Ross Dependency](/wiki/Ross_Dependency "Ross Dependency"), comprise the [Realm of New Zealand](/wiki/Realm_of_New_Zealand "Realm of New Zealand").

His power within the Vatican City State is unlimited by any constitution, but all persons resident within the Vatican have consented to obey the Pope, either by virtue of being ordained Catholic clergy or members of the [Swiss Guard](/wiki/Swiss_Guard "Swiss Guard").

Candidates for both the Assembly of Experts and the presidency are vetted by the appointed [Guardian Council](/wiki/Guardian_Council "Guardian Council").
